TopicTitle: Applying reverse thrust to a much loved franchise!

Articles.Content:
Ok, let's start at the beginning, price point. I've purchased KSP(console) either got KSP: Enhanced Edition(other console) free or at a reduced price, and KSP for PC, along with all the DLC on console and for the PC. I think I paid 30ish dollars for all 3 copies of the base game. But now, the price is 50 dollars for just the base game, and we know there is going to be DLC down the road. A lot of changes have been made from KSP to KSP 2 we get it, they are different games, but you've claimed accessibility as one of the reasons for a lot of the changes. Where is the accessibility in pricing?

The price point will make the game less accessible, sure those wanting to ride a nostalgia wave will pay it. But, you won't be getting content creators buying and distributing 50 copies of the game in a single stream at that price. But, you want KSP 2 to be accessible to more people, right? 

I was there, 3,000 crashes ago before auto struts were a thing. I was there when missions failed because 1 manual strut didn't attach on both sides. I was there when manual struts applied drag making launch vehicles unstable in flight. I was there when manual struts were a ∆v tax on all launches in an atmosphere. Here I am again, like a rat on a sinking ship being dragged backward into the water instead of being to move forward. I am shocked and miffed that such a small quality of life change was ignored on release. Do you think weak attachment points makes KSP 2 more accessible to new players? (Let me tell you, manual strutting was a HUGE time tax, and one of the least fun aspects when I started in KSP)

I can't tell you how excited I was to hear about KSP 2. Even with the events surrounding the turbulent development, I was excited. Bouncing in my seat excited. Kid going on a field trip excited. Then to see the price point, and lack of auto struts on EA release bringing back the limp, flaccid, floppy rockets of yesterdecade, I feel like you crushed a little of my inner child. You are dragging the KSP backward with these decisions.

I'll see you at a sale on this, maybe.
Sadly I have to agree. This feels like an old version of KSP 1 with weird UI and control decisions added onto it.
